Ne determines the level of genetic diversity and the effectiveness of natural selection in a population. Humans have remarkably low genetic diversity compared to most other primates—chimpanzees have ~2-3x higher nucleotide diversity despite a smaller census population.

questions.question: Genome editing has raised the possibility of 'gene drives'—genetic engineering systems that can spread modified alleles through wild populations. How does a CRISPR-based gene drive work?
options: The gene drive encodes Cas9 and a guide RNA that cuts the wild-type allele on the homologous chromosome, forcing the cell to repair using the gene drive allele as template, converting heterozygotes to homozygotes
Gene drives work by infecting organisms with viruses carrying the modified gene
The modified gene simply outcompetes wild-type alleles through natural selection
Gene drives use radiation to mutate all copies of a gene simultaneously
questions.explanation: CRISPR-based gene drives exploit homology-directed repair (HDR) to spread engineered alleles through populations at rates exceeding Mendelian inheritance: (1) The gene drive cassette contains Cas9 and a guide RNA targeting the corresponding wild-type allele. (2) In heterozygous individuals (one drive allele, one wild-type), Cas9 cuts the wild-type allele. (3) The cell repairs the double-strand break using the drive-containing chromosome as a template (HDR), copying the entire drive cassette to the repaired chromosome. (4) The organism becomes homozygous for the drive allele. (5) All offspring inherit the drive. This can spread the engineered allele to >99% of a population within a few generations. Applications include suppressing malaria mosquitoes, but ecological risks of releasing gene drives are a major concern.

questions.question: Paleogenomics—the sequencing of ancient DNA—has revolutionized our understanding of human evolution. What is the primary technical challenge in ancient DNA (aDNA) work?
options: Ancient DNA is identical to modern DNA and provides no new information
DNA degradation produces short, damaged fragments (typically <100 bp), often contaminated with modern DNA and microbial DNA, requiring specialized extraction and library preparation
Ancient DNA is too stable and does not degrade
Ancient organisms had different nucleotide bases than modern organisms
questions.explanation: Ancient DNA presents multiple technical challenges: (1) Fragmentation—DNA degrades over time through hydrolysis and oxidation, producing fragments typically <100 bp (often <50 bp). (2) Chemical damage—deamination of cytosine to uracil (C→T transitions, the most common aDNA damage pattern) creates miscoding lesions. (3) Contamination—modern human DNA (from researchers, lab surfaces) easily contaminates samples, and microbial DNA from decomposition vastly outnumbers endogenous DNA. (4) Low endogenous DNA content—often <1% of extracted DNA is from the target organism. Solutions include: cleanroom facilities, enzymatic treatment of damaged bases (USER enzyme), computational authentication of damage patterns, and ultra-efficient library preparation methods optimized for short fragments.

questions.question: Genome annotation involves identifying all functional elements in a genome sequence. What is the difference between structural annotation and functional annotation?
options: Structural annotation is only used for bacterial genomes
They are identical processes
Structural annotation determines protein structure; functional annotation determines DNA structure
Structural annotation identifies gene locations (exons, introns, regulatory elements); functional annotation assigns biological roles to identified genes
questions.explanation: Genome annotation occurs in two stages: (1) Structural annotation identifies the genomic positions of genes and other functional elements—locating exons, introns, UTRs, splice sites, promoters, and non-coding RNA genes. Methods include: ab initio gene prediction (algorithms like Augustus, GENSCAN), homology-based prediction (comparing to known genes), and experimental evidence (RNA-seq, EST alignments). (2) Functional annotation assigns biological roles to identified genes—predicting protein function based on: homology to characterized genes (BLAST), protein domain analysis (Pfam, InterPro), gene ontology assignment, pathway mapping (KEGG), and experimental validation. Functional annotation is more challenging, as ~20-40% of genes in most genomes have unknown function.

questions.question: The selfish DNA theory proposes that transposable elements persist because they replicate faster than they can be eliminated by selection. This theory views TEs primarily as:
options: Genomic parasites that spread within genomes due to their ability to self-replicate, with most insertions being neutral or slightly deleterious
Immune defense elements against viral infection
The primary source of all genetic innovation
Essential structural components of chromosomes
questions.explanation: The selfish DNA theory (Orgel & Crick, 1980; Doolittle & Sapienza, 1980) proposes that TEs persist simply because they replicate within genomes faster than host selection can eliminate them—they are genomic parasites. Key arguments: (1) TE copy-and-paste mechanisms increase their copy number with each transposition event. (2) Most TE insertions are in non-functional DNA (by chance) and are effectively neutral. (3) The few insertions that are deleterious are removed by purifying selection, but this doesn't eliminate TEs that have already replicated. (4) The equilibrium between TE replication and host defense (piRNA, DNA methylation) determines TE content. However, this view has been moderated by evidence that some TEs have been exapted for host functions.

questions.question: A researcher compares the genomes of two bacterial species: Species A has 5.0 Mb genome with 4,500 genes, while Species B has 1.5 Mb genome with 1,300 genes. Species B is an obligate intracellular pathogen. Predict which functional gene categories are most likely to be reduced or absent in Species B.
options: Genes for DNA replication and translation
Genes for amino acid biosynthesis, de novo nucleotide synthesis, and energy metabolism, since these can be obtained from the host cell
Genes for protein folding
No gene categories should differ between the two species
questions.explanation: Obligate intracellular pathogens undergo predictable patterns of genome reduction: genes for biosynthesis of nutrients available from the host are the first to be lost. Species B would most likely lack or have reduced: (1) Amino acid biosynthesis pathways—all or most amino acids can be imported from the host cytoplasm. (2) De novo nucleotide synthesis—nucleotides can be obtained from host pools. (3) Fatty acid synthesis—membrane lipids can be derived from the host. (4) Energy metabolism may be reduced—some intracellular parasites (e.g., Chlamydia, Rickettsia) use host ATP via ATP/ADP translocases. Genes for core information processing (replication, transcription, translation), host-cell interaction, and membrane transport are typically retained. This pattern is consistently observed across independent lineages of intracellular pathogens.

questions.question: Phylogenomic analysis uses genome-scale data (hundreds to thousands of genes) for phylogenetic reconstruction. What advantage does phylogenomics provide over single-gene phylogenies?
options: Genome-scale data averaging across many genes reduces the stochastic error inherent in single-gene trees, and can detect conflicting signals from horizontal gene transfer or incomplete lineage sorting
Phylogenomics always produces perfectly resolved trees
Phylogenomics only works for bacterial genomes
Single-gene phylogenies are always more accurate
questions.explanation: Phylogenomics provides several advantages: (1) Statistical power—concatenating or summarizing hundreds of gene alignments reduces stochastic error (noise) that affects individual gene trees, improving phylogenetic resolution. (2) Conflict detection—comparing individual gene trees reveals conflicts caused by incomplete lineage sorting (ILS), horizontal gene transfer, gene duplication/loss, or introgression. (3) Methods like species-tree estimation (ASTRAL, SVDquartets) explicitly model gene tree-species tree discordance. (4) Genome-wide data can resolve rapid radiations and deep divergences that single genes cannot. However, phylogenomics also faces challenges: systematic errors can be amplified with more data, and model misspecification affects all genes. Taxon sampling, data quality, and appropriate models remain critical.

questions.question: A researcher hypothesizes that a specific long non-coding RNA (lncRNA) is essential for maintaining stem cell pluripotency. What experimental approach would most directly test this hypothesis?
options: Overexpress the lncRNA and measure stem cell growth rate
Sequence the lncRNA to determine its complete sequence
Use CRISPRi (dCas9-KRAB) to knock down the lncRNA and assess whether stem cells lose pluripotency markers (Oct4, Sox2, Nanog) and spontaneously differentiate
Compare lncRNA expression between different tissues
questions.explanation: CRISPRi (CRISPR interference using catalytically dead dCas9 fused to the KRAB repressor domain) is ideal for lncRNA knockdown because: (1) It represses transcription at the lncRNA's genomic locus, avoiding artifacts from post-transcriptional knockdown (RNAi may not effectively target nuclear-localized lncRNAs). (2) Unlike CRISPR knockout, CRISPRi doesn't delete DNA sequences that might have independent regulatory functions (the genomic locus itself might serve as an enhancer). (3) Knockdown is reversible. The researcher should then assess: pluripotency markers (Oct4, Sox2, Nanog) by qPCR/immunofluorescence, differentiation markers, colony morphology, and functional pluripotency (teratoma formation, chimera contribution). Rescue experiments (restoring the lncRNA from an exogenous promoter) would confirm specificity.

questions.question: Biased gene conversion (BGC) is a molecular process during meiotic recombination that favors the repair of heteroduplex DNA mismatches toward GC base pairs. What evolutionary consequence does BGC have on genome composition?
options: BGC has no effect on genome evolution
BGC only affects mitochondrial genomes
BGC drives local GC enrichment in regions of high recombination, mimicking the signature of positive selection
BGC decreases GC content over time
questions.explanation: Biased gene conversion (BGC) occurs during meiotic recombination when heteroduplex DNA (formed between maternal and paternal chromosomes at recombination sites) contains mismatches. The mismatch repair system preferentially converts A:T base pairs to G:C pairs, introducing a transmission bias favoring GC alleles. Evolutionary consequences: (1) Regions of high recombination accumulate higher GC content over time (contributing to isochore structure in mammalian genomes). (2) BGC can drive fixation of GC alleles even if they are slightly deleterious, mimicking positive selection signatures (elevated dN/dS). (3) BGC may confound molecular evolution analyses that assume mutations are selectively neutral. BGC is now recognized as a significant non-adaptive evolutionary force shaping genome composition, particularly in regions of high recombination.

questions.question:
Evaluate these statements about genome evolution:
I. Genome size correlates well with organismal complexity across all domains of life
II. Gene duplication followed by divergence is a major source of evolutionary novelty
III. Exon shuffling can create novel proteins by combining exons from different genes
IV. Horizontal gene transfer has significantly contributed to prokaryotic genome evolution
options: FTTT
TTTT
TFTT
FTTF
questions.explanation: I. FALSE: The C-value paradox demonstrates that genome size does NOT correlate with organismal complexity. The onion genome (16 Gb) is 5x larger than the human genome; some amoebas have genomes >100x larger than humans. Genome size variation is largely driven by repetitive element content, not gene number or organismal complexity. II. TRUE: Gene duplication creates redundant copies that can diverge (neofunctionalization, subfunctionalization) without losing the original function, providing raw material for new genes. III. TRUE: Exon shuffling recombines exons from different genes (often through retrotransposition or recombination between introns), creating chimeric proteins with novel domain combinations. IV. TRUE: HGT is pervasive in prokaryotes and has distributed genes for antibiotic resistance, metabolic capabilities, and virulence factors across bacterial lineages.

questions.question:
Evaluate these statements about transposable elements:
I. DNA transposons move by a 'cut-and-paste' mechanism using transposase
II. Retrotransposons move by a 'copy-and-paste' mechanism via an RNA intermediate
III. Transposable elements comprise less than 1% of the human genome
IV. Some transposable element-derived sequences have been co-opted for host genome function (exaptation)
options: TTFT
TTTT
TFFT
TFTF
questions.explanation: I. TRUE: DNA transposons (Class II TEs) use transposase to excise from one location and insert at another (cut-and-paste). Terminal inverted repeats (TIRs) are recognized by transposase. Most DNA transposons in the human genome are now inactive. II. TRUE: Retrotransposons (Class I TEs) transpose via an RNA intermediate: DNA → RNA (transcription) → cDNA (reverse transcription) → new insertion (integration). Copy-and-paste increases copy number. III. FALSE: TEs comprise approximately 45% of the human genome, not <1%. SINEs (~13%), LINEs (~20%), LTR retrotransposons (~8%), DNA transposons (~3%), and their degraded remnants make up nearly half the genome. IV. TRUE: Many TE-derived sequences have been exapted/domesticated for host functions, including regulatory elements, structural chromatin components, and even protein-coding genes (e.g., syncytin from retroviral env gene).

questions.question:
Evaluate these statements about the evolution of genome size:
I. Polyploidy (whole-genome duplication) is a common mechanism of genome size increase in plants
II. Transposable element proliferation is the primary mechanism of genome size increase in mammals
III. Genome reduction commonly occurs in obligate intracellular symbionts and parasites
IV. Genome size is always strongly correlated with phenotypic complexity
options: TTTF
TTTT
TTFT
TFTT
questions.explanation: I. TRUE: Polyploidy is extremely common in plant evolution. An estimated 15% of speciation events in angiosperms involve polyploidy. Most crop plants are polyploid (wheat 6x, cotton 4x, potato 4x). II. TRUE: In mammals, genome size variation is largely driven by transposable element content. TEs comprise ~45% of the human genome. Species with more active TEs tend to have larger genomes. III. TRUE: Obligate intracellular organisms undergo massive genome reduction because host-provided metabolites make many biosynthetic genes dispensable. Mycoplasma genitalium (580 kb), Buchnera aphidicola (420 kb), and mitochondrial genomes (16 kb in humans) illustrate extreme reduction. IV. FALSE: The C-value paradox demonstrates no strong correlation between genome size and complexity. The onion genome is 5x larger than the human genome; some amoebas have genomes 200x larger.

questions.question:
Evaluate these statements about horizontal gene transfer (HGT) in eukaryotes:
I. HGT is common in prokaryotes but extremely rare in multicellular eukaryotes
II. The endosymbiotic transfer of genes from mitochondria and chloroplasts to the nuclear genome is a form of HGT
III. Some plants have acquired genes from parasitic plants through HGT
IV. HGT never occurs between different domains of life
options: FTFT
FTFF
FTTF
TTFF
questions.explanation: I. FALSE: While HGT is less common in eukaryotes than prokaryotes, it is not extremely rare. Examples are increasingly being documented, especially in protists, fungi, and some animals (e.g., bdelloid rotifers have substantial HGT). II. TRUE: Endosymbiotic gene transfer (EGT) from organellar genomes to the nuclear genome is a specific type of HGT that has occurred extensively. Over 1,000 genes have been transferred from mitochondria to the nucleus over evolutionary time, and similar transfer has occurred from chloroplasts. III. TRUE: Parasitic plants (e.g., Striga, Cuscuta) have been shown to acquire genes from their host plants through horizontal transfer, facilitated by the intimate physical connection between parasite and host. IV. FALSE: HGT occurs between domains—bacterial genes have been found in some eukaryotic genomes, and archaeal genes in bacteria. The original endosymbiotic events themselves represented cross-domain gene transfer.

questions.question:
Evaluate these statements about non-coding RNA in genome evolution:
I. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are short (~22 nt) non-coding RNAs that regulate gene expression post-transcriptionally
II. The number of miRNA genes tends to increase with organismal complexity across animal evolution
III. Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) evolve more rapidly than protein-coding genes
IV. All transcribed sequences in the genome encode functional non-coding RNAs
options: TTTF
TTTT
TTFT
TFTT
questions.explanation: I. TRUE: miRNAs are ~22 nt RNAs processed from hairpin precursors by Drosha and Dicer, loaded into RISC/Argonaute to guide translational repression or mRNA degradation of targets with complementary seed sequences. II. TRUE: miRNA gene number correlates with morphological complexity in animals: C. elegans ~250, Drosophila ~250, zebrafish ~350, mouse ~700, human ~2,600. New miRNA genes appear at evolutionary transitions associated with increased complexity. III. TRUE: lncRNAs show lower sequence conservation than protein-coding genes, evolving ~5-10x faster. However, some lncRNAs show conserved secondary structure or syntenic position despite sequence divergence. IV. FALSE: While the genome is pervasively transcribed (~85% by some estimates), most transcription is likely non-functional noise. Not all transcribed sequences produce functional ncRNAs—many represent transcriptional artifacts, processing intermediates, or neutral transcription from accessible chromatin.

questions.question: A Ks (synonymous substitution rate) analysis of 5,000 paralogous gene pairs in a plant genome produces a histogram with: a large peak at Ks = 0.01-0.05, a prominent peak at Ks = 0.3-0.4, and a smaller peak at Ks = 0.8-1.0. What evolutionary history does this distribution indicate?
options: A single WGD followed by gene conversion that homogenized some pairs but not others
Two waves of tandem gene duplication caused by transposable element activity bursts at specific times
The peaks are artifacts of molecular clock inaccuracy in plant genomes with no biological significance

Two ancient whole-genome duplication events — the peak at Ks 0.3-0.4 represents a more recent WGD and the peak at 0.8-1.0 represents an older WGD, as WGDs produce many simultaneously duplicated pairs that accumulate synonymous substitutions at similar rates creating characteristic peaks
questions.explanation: Ks distribution analysis is the primary method for detecting ancient WGDs in plant genomes. After WGD, all genes are simultaneously duplicated. As pairs diverge, their Ks values cluster around a single value corresponding to 2μt. Multiple WGDs at different times create multiple peaks. Using typical plant synonymous rate (~6.5 × 10^-9/site/year): Ks 0.35 → ~27 MYA; Ks 0.9 → ~69 MYA. The low-Ks peak (0.01-0.05) represents continuous small-scale tandem duplications. Real examples: Arabidopsis shows three WGD peaks (alpha ~47 MYA, beta ~60 MYA, gamma ~130 MYA). Most angiosperms have undergone at least one WGD. Caveats include Ks saturation at high values, rate variation among genes, and gene conversion creating artificially low Ks.
questions.topic: Ks Distribution Analysis for Paleopolyploidy Detection

questions.question: The ENCODE project reported that approximately 80% of the human genome has biochemical function. Why was this finding controversial among evolutionary biologists?
options: Evolutionary biologists accepted the 80% figure unanimously with no controversy
The controversy was about ENCODE's sequencing technology being inaccurate

Evolutionary biologists argued that biochemical activity (TF binding, histone modification, transcription) does not necessarily imply biological function — only ~5-10% of the genome shows evolutionary constraint across mammals, and the genetic load argument makes 80% functionality incompatible with observed mutation rates and population sizes
ENCODE actually found only 2% of the genome is functional, and biologists objected because this was already known
questions.explanation: ENCODE (2012) claimed ~80.4% of the genome participates in at least one biochemical event (transcription, TF binding, histone modification, chromatin accessibility). Critics (Graur et al. 2013, Doolittle 2013) argued ENCODE conflated biochemical activity with biological function. Key counterarguments: (1) Low-affinity TF binding occurs genome-wide by mass action without functional significance. (2) Pervasive transcription may be noise. (3) Only ~5-10% shows evolutionary constraint (purifying selection). (4) Genetic load: if 80% is functional, ~80 of 100 de novo mutations/generation would be deleterious, incompatible with viable populations. The dispute is largely semantic — 'selected effect' definition gives ~5-15%, 'causal role' definition gives ~80%. Most biologists agree the truth is between 5% and 80%.
questions.topic: ENCODE Controversy and Genome Functionality Debate

questions.question: A researcher wants to definitively test whether a conserved non-coding sequence functions as a limb-specific enhancer. Which experimental approach provides the most rigorous evidence?
options: Combine multiple approaches: (1) transgenic reporter assay (clone sequence upstream of minimal promoter-lacZ and test in mouse embryos); (2) CRISPR-Cas9 deletion from the endogenous locus to assess limb phenotypes; (3) ChIP-seq for H3K27ac to confirm active enhancer marks in limb tissue; and (4) chromosome conformation capture to verify physical contact with the target gene promoter
Transfect the sequence into fibroblasts with a luciferase reporter and test for enhanced activity
Perform bioinformatic analysis showing conservation across vertebrates and presence of predicted TF binding motifs
Measure mRNA levels of the nearby gene in limb tissue and assume the element is an enhancer if the gene is expressed
questions.explanation: Definitive enhancer identification requires multiple complementary lines of evidence. Transgenic reporter assay is the gold standard in vivo test — if the sequence drives reporter expression in limb buds, it has enhancer activity (used in the VISTA Enhancer Browser project with >3,000 tested candidates). CRISPR deletion tests necessity in the endogenous context — e.g., ZRS enhancer deletion causes limb truncation. ChIP-seq for H3K27ac confirms active enhancer chromatin state (H3K4me1+/H3K27ac+ = active enhancer). Chromosome conformation capture (4C-seq/Capture-C) verifies physical enhancer-promoter contact, essential since enhancers can act over 1 Mb distances. Bioinformatics alone suggests but doesn't prove function. Wrong cell type (fibroblasts) misses tissue-specific cofactors.

questions.question: Gene conversion in the MHC (major histocompatibility complex) plays a diversifying role opposite to its homogenizing function in rRNA genes. How does gene conversion contribute to MHC polymorphism?
options: Gene conversion at MHC loci converts functional genes into pseudogenes, reducing the effective gene pool
MHC polymorphism arises exclusively from point mutations with no contribution from gene conversion
Gene conversion only homogenizes MHC sequences, reducing diversity to a single allele per locus

Short sequence segments (50-200 bp) are copied between different MHC alleles during recombination, creating mosaic alleles with shuffled polymorphic segments — combined with point mutation and balancing selection, this generates extraordinary allelic diversity with thousands of alleles at HLA loci
questions.explanation: Gene conversion serves a diversifying role in MHC evolution. The MHC/HLA system is the most polymorphic genetic system known (HLA-B alone has >6,000 alleles), maintained by balancing selection for pathogen resistance. Gene conversion transfers short segments between different HLA alleles or between HLA genes during meiotic recombination, creating mosaic alleles with recombined polymorphic segments. Evidence: many HLA alleles appear as mosaics of segments from other alleles with breakpoints at recombination hotspots. Also seen in chicken immunoglobulin diversification (gene conversion from pseudo-V segments in the bursa) and Trypanosoma VSG switching for antigenic variation. This contrasts with the homogenizing role in rRNA genes and histones.
questions.topic: Gene Conversion Diversifying Role in MHC Evolution

questions.question: Genomic imprinting results in monoallelic, parent-of-origin-specific gene expression. What molecular mechanism establishes imprinting marks?
options: Imprinting marks are established after birth in response to dietary signals and change throughout life
Imprinting is identical to X-inactivation and uses the same XIST-based mechanism on autosomes
Imprinting is determined by DNA sequence differences between maternal and paternal alleles, not epigenetic marks

Differential DNA methylation at imprinting control regions established during gametogenesis by DNMT3A/DNMT3L in a sex-specific manner — these marks resist the genome-wide demethylation of early embryogenesis, maintained by DNMT1 and protected by ZFP57/KAP1, resulting in lifelong parent-specific expression
questions.explanation: Genomic imprinting uses sex-specific DNA methylation at imprinting control regions (ICRs). Process: (1) Erasure in primordial germ cells (~E11.5 in mice) by TET-mediated active demethylation. (2) Re-establishment: DNMT3A with cofactor DNMT3L methylates specific ICRs during oogenesis (~20 maternal ICRs) or spermatogenesis (~3-4 paternal ICRs). DNMT3L recognizes unmethylated H3K4. (3) Maintenance: imprinting marks survive genome-wide demethylation in preimplantation embryos through DNMT1/UHRF1 activity and protection by ZFP57/KAP1 complex. Imprinted methylation controls gene expression by blocking CTCF binding (H19-IGF2 locus), silencing promoters, or regulating lncRNAs (Airn, Kcnq1ot1). ~150 imprinted genes known, many involved in growth regulation (consistent with parental conflict theory).

questions.question: A GWAS for height identifies 150 associated SNPs. Only 12 (8%) fall in exons, 85 (57%) are intergenic, and 53 (35%) are intronic. All 150 explain only 20% of estimated heritability. What is the most complete interpretation?
options: The intergenic SNPs are false positives because variants outside genes cannot affect phenotype
The results prove height is primarily environmental since only 20% heritability is explained by genetics
All 150 SNPs must be in linkage disequilibrium with nearby protein-coding mutations that are the true causal variants

Most trait-associated variants affect gene regulation rather than protein structure, with GWAS hits in intergenic and intronic regions likely overlapping enhancers or other cis-regulatory elements — the missing heritability (80%) may involve rare variants, epistasis, structural variants, and many common variants of very small effect below detection threshold
questions.explanation: GWAS consistently shows >90% of trait-associated variants fall outside protein-coding regions across all complex traits. Many overlap enhancer marks (H3K4me1, H3K27ac), DNase hypersensitive sites, and TF binding sites identified by ENCODE. Non-coding variants can alter TF binding affinity, disrupt chromatin looping, affect lncRNA/miRNA activity, or change splicing. Missing heritability explanations: rare variants (MAF <1%) with larger effects, epistasis, gene-environment interactions, structural variants (CNVs), and the omnigenic model (Boyle et al. 2017) suggesting essentially all genes in relevant cell types contribute. For height, >3,000 loci now identified in GWAS of >700,000 individuals, explaining ~40% heritability. Option C confuses GWAS-explained variance with total heritability.
questions.topic: GWAS Interpretation and Regulatory Variant Predominance

questions.question: The piRNA (Piwi-interacting RNA) pathway is a major defense mechanism against transposable elements in animal germlines. How does this pathway silence transposons?
options: piRNAs directly edit transposon DNA sequences through base modification, permanently inactivating mobile elements by mutating their coding regions

piRNAs (24-31 nt) associate with PIWI-clade Argonaute proteins to silence transposons both post-transcriptionally (by cleaving TE mRNAs via the ping-pong amplification cycle) and transcriptionally (by directing DNA methylation and heterochromatin formation at TE loci), ensuring genome integrity across generations
piRNAs function exclusively in somatic cells and have no role in protecting germline genomes from transposition
The piRNA pathway is identical to the siRNA pathway and uses Dicer to process transposon-derived dsRNA
questions.explanation: The piRNA pathway is the primary transposon defense in animal germlines. piRNAs are 24-31 nt (longer than miRNAs/siRNAs), generated from piRNA clusters (genomic loci containing TE fragments). They associate with PIWI-clade proteins (MIWI, MILI, MIWI2 in mice; Piwi, Aubergine, AGO3 in Drosophila). Post-transcriptional silencing: the ping-pong cycle amplifies piRNAs — sense piRNAs (from TE mRNAs) guide cleavage of antisense transcripts and vice versa, creating a self-reinforcing loop. Transcriptional silencing: MIWI2-piRNA complexes direct de novo DNA methylation (via DNMT3L/DNMT3A) and H3K9me3 deposition at TE genomic loci. This epigenetic silencing is heritable. piRNAs are Dicer-independent (unlike miRNAs/siRNAs). Loss of piRNA pathway components leads to transposon derepression, DNA damage, and male sterility in mice.
questions.topic: piRNA Pathway and Transposon Defense in Germlines

questions.question: Chromothripsis is a recently discovered phenomenon in cancer genomics. What does it involve?
options: The gradual fragmentation of chromosomes over many cell divisions due to progressive telomere shortening
A normal process during meiotic recombination where chromosomes exchange segments at hundreds of points simultaneously

A single catastrophic event where one or a few chromosomes shatter into tens to hundreds of fragments that are then randomly reassembled by error-prone DNA repair mechanisms — resulting in massive chromosomal rearrangements, gene fusions, copy number changes, and chromatin restructuring in a single cell division rather than through gradual accumulation
The organized dismantling of chromosomes during programmed cell death (apoptosis)
questions.explanation: Chromothripsis (Greek: chromos = chromosome, thripsis = shattering) was discovered by Stephens et al. (2011). A chromosome or chromosomal region undergoes catastrophic shattering (possibly during mitosis when chromosomes are trapped in micronuclei, or through replication stress) producing tens to hundreds of fragments. These are reassembled by non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) or microhomology-mediated break-induced replication (MMBIR), resulting in massively rearranged chromosomes with random fragment order and orientation. Some fragments are lost, causing deletions. Found in 2-3% of all cancers and up to 25% of bone cancers. Can simultaneously inactivate multiple tumor suppressors and activate oncogenes through gene fusions. Also described in germline (constitutional chromothripsis in congenital disorders). Related: chromoplexy (multiple inter-chromosomal translocations in a single event).

questions.question: A researcher wants to determine whether two distantly related bacterial species acquired the same antibiotic resistance gene through horizontal gene transfer from a common source or through convergent evolution. Which evidence would most strongly support HGT?
options: The two species inhabit similar ecological niches, suggesting parallel selection pressure

The resistance gene in both species has nearly identical nucleotide sequence (>95%) despite the species having only ~60% genome-wide sequence identity, and the gene has different GC content from the surrounding chromosomal DNA in both species, flanked by integrase genes and IS elements
Both species have the same number of total genes, suggesting similar evolutionary pressures
Both species are resistant to the same antibiotic, regardless of the mechanism involved
questions.explanation: HGT detection relies on multiple lines of evidence: (1) Sequence identity disparity: if a gene is >95% identical between species that are only ~60% similar genome-wide, the gene was likely acquired recently from a common source rather than vertically inherited (which would predict ~60% identity). (2) Compositional bias: different GC content from surrounding DNA suggests the gene originated from an organism with different base composition and hasn't yet undergone 'amelioration' (convergence to host GC content). (3) Flanking mobile elements: presence of integrase genes, insertion sequences (IS elements), direct repeats, or association with genomic islands, integrative conjugative elements (ICEs), or plasmids provides the mechanism of transfer. (4) Phylogenetic incongruence: gene tree differing from species tree (the gene clusters the two bacteria together rather than with their closest relatives). Antibiotic resistance alone doesn't prove HGT — could be convergent mutation. Niche similarity suggests selection pressure but not mechanism.

questions.question: Metagenomics has revealed that unculturable microorganisms vastly outnumber culturable ones. What fundamental insight about genome diversity has environmental metagenomics provided?
options: Metagenomics showed that all environmental microorganisms have identical genomes adapted to the same ecological niche
Environmental metagenomics demonstrated that only bacteria live in extreme environments, with no archaea or viruses present

Metagenomic sequencing of environmental samples has revealed that over 99% of microbial species have never been cultured in the laboratory, and their genomes contain vast numbers of novel gene families with no homologs in existing databases — this microbial dark matter dramatically expands the known protein fold space and metabolic pathway diversity
Metagenomic studies proved that horizontal gene transfer never occurs in natural environments
questions.explanation: Environmental metagenomics (culture-independent sequencing of DNA from environmental samples) has revolutionized our understanding of microbial diversity. Key findings: >99% of environmental microorganisms resist cultivation by standard methods (the 'great plate count anomaly'). Tara Oceans project sequenced global ocean microbiomes, discovering ~40 million genes, most with no database homologs. Human Gut Metagenome: >10 million non-redundant genes identified, many encoding novel functions. 'Microbial dark matter': entire phyla (e.g., candidate phyla radiation, CPR — Patescibacteria) were discovered only through metagenomics, with no cultured representatives. These organisms have extremely small genomes (0.5-1.0 Mb) and reduced metabolic capabilities, suggesting obligate symbiotic/parasitic lifestyles. Novel enzymes discovered through metagenomics (cellulases, lipases, antibiotics) have biotechnology applications. Viral metagenomics revealed that viruses are the most abundant biological entities on Earth (~10^31 total).
questions.topic: Metagenomics and Microbial Genome Dark Matter

questions.question:
Evaluate these statements about comparative model organism genomics:

S1: Saccharomyces cerevisiae (12 Mb, ~6,000 genes) was the first eukaryotic genome sequenced (1996) and approximately 30% of its genes have identifiable homologs in the human genome.
S2: Drosophila melanogaster has approximately the same number of protein-coding genes (~14,000) as C. elegans (~20,000).
S3: The mouse genome shares approximately 99% nucleotide identity with human coding sequences, making it the closest model organism to humans.
S4: Arabidopsis thaliana (135 Mb, ~27,000 genes) contains more protein-coding genes than the human genome, partly due to ancient whole-genome duplication events.
options: TFFT
TTTT
TTFT
TFTF
questions.explanation: S1 TRUE: S. cerevisiae was sequenced in 1996 (Goffeau et al.), 12.1 Mb across 16 chromosomes, ~6,275 genes. ~30% have human homologs, enabling yeast as a model for cell cycle, DNA repair, and metabolism. S2 FALSE: Drosophila has ~14,000 genes but C. elegans has ~20,000 — these are NOT approximately the same. Drosophila actually has fewer genes despite arguably greater morphological complexity, which itself is an interesting paradox. S3 FALSE: Mouse-human coding sequence identity is ~85%, not ~99%. The ~99% figure applies to human-chimpanzee comparison. Mouse and human diverged ~90 MYA vs human-chimp ~6-7 MYA. Mouse shares ~80% of genes as 1:1 orthologs with humans. S4 TRUE: Arabidopsis was sequenced in 2000, has ~27,000 protein-coding genes — more than human (~20,000-25,000). This is due to ancient WGD events (at least three: alpha, beta, gamma) plus extensive tandem duplications (~17% of genes in tandem arrays).
